0.body:
Straits Chinese Restaurant is located at Cecil Street, Straits Chinese Nonya Restaurant is one of three establishments by Guan Hoe Soon, the oldest Nonya Restaurant in Singapore, located in Singapore's Central Business District area since 1984.

Using secret recipes handed down through the generations, the restaurant offers a wide selection of dishes that maintain the original taste of an Authentic Peranakan cuisine, using only the freshest ingredients and spices. Straits Chinese Nonya Restaurant is part of a restaurant list featured in Michelin Guide Singapore.
0.name: Straits Chinese Restaurant

2.body:
Established since 12 July 1990, the award-winning Xin Cuisine Chinese Restaurant brings you the finest Cantonese delicacies and intricate dim sums crafted by a team of Master Chefs. Loved by locals and guests alike, its signature Homestyle Roast Duck with Tea Leaves and Poached Rice with Seafood in Superior Broth served with Crispy Rice are not to be missed. Intimate private dining rooms are also available for business or social gatherings.

SIGNATURE DISHES
- Xin's Signature Home-style Roast Duck with Tea Leaves
- Deep-fried Prawns coated with Yuzu Mayonnaise
- Stir-fried Wagyu Beef Cubes with Black Pepper and Longan
- Poached Rice with Seafood in Superior Broth served with Crispy Rice

DIM SUM BUFFET
Indulge in perennial favourites such as Steamed Barbecued Pork Bun, Custard Bun with Salted Egg Yolk, Shrimp Dumpling with Fish Roe (Har Kow) and tantalize your taste buds with Xin's selection of soup, noodle/congee, dessert. Available from Wednesdays to Fridays, lunch only.

WEDDINGS AT XIN CUISINE
Xin Cuisine Chinese Restaurant is a prestige venue for small intimate weddings with an award-winning spread that will satisfy your gastronomic pleasures.
2.description: Awarding-winning Cantonese Cuisine with Intricate Dim Sum
2.name: XIN CUISINE CHINESE RESTAURANT

3.body:
Discover modern Cantonese cuisine in a Chinese restaurant like no other. Located where Bugis Street meets Bras-Basah in one of Singapore’s more authentic areas, Song Garden gives you an unforgettable taste of the city’s culinary excellence. Our skillful chefs have elaborated a mouth-watering array of contemporary dishes. Pleasing to the eye, exquisite on the tastebuds – expect a dash of wow factor in each and every one. The setting is elegant. Filled with daylight at lunchtime, cozy when night falls, the main restaurant and six private dining rooms feature traditional Chinese furnishings and paintings. Ideal for banquets and business lunches in Singapore.

Weekdays Lunch: 11.30am to 2.30pm

Dinner: 6pm to 10pm

Weekends/ Public Holiday Lunch: 11am to 3pm

Dinner: 6pm to 10pm

address.buildingName: Song Garden, Level 2, Mercure Singapore Bugis

3.name: SONG GARDEN CHINESE RESTAURANT

4.body: Hwang Sil serves Korean and Chinese cuisine. They offer Boiled Dumplings, Shredded Pork with Sauce, Sweet & Sour Pork and many more. Come and enjoy their delicious dishes with your friends and family!
4.name: Hwang Sil Korean Chinese Restaurant

5.body: Just as the name of the restaurant suggests, Oriental Chinese Restaurant offers only the most authentic and best of Northeastern and Sichuan cuisine. Beyond just the food, the  friendly staff as well the warmth of the ambience will make you feel at home. If you're looking for a place to relax with family and friends after work over good food, Oriental Chinese Restaurant is the perfect choice!
5.name: Oriental Chinese Restaurant 东北美食

6.body: From the ambience to the food options, this eatery will keep you steeped in local Chinese culture with authentic dishes.
6.description: Authentic Halal Chinese Restaurant in Kampong Gelam
6.name: The Fortune Cookie

7.body: Experience the Sichuan- Chinese dish loved by locals, Mala Xiang Guo. Caution: Mala translates to spicy and numbing, so come prepared!
7.description: Halal Chinese food in Kampong Gelam
7.name: Le Fuse

8.body: Formerly known as Chinois, this Chinese fine dining restaurant at Hotel Michael™ sees celebrity chef Susur Lee’s signature contemporary Chinese dishes sharing the spotlight with senior executive chef Ken Ling’s fiery Hunanese and Teochew delights. The signature Roast London Duck, with its crispy aromatic skin and succulent duck meat, is a must-order. Visitors should also try the restaurant’s Singapore Slaw, chef Susur’s twist on the local yusheng salad that is traditionally eaten during Chinese New Year. Vegetarian menus are available in the restaurant, which also has three private rooms that can seat four to 12 for groups who prefer private dining.
8.description: This Chinese fine dining restaurant dishes out Chinese, Hunanese and Teochew delights.

address.buildingName: Resorts World™ Sentosa, Hotel Michael Lobby

8.name: Tunglok Heen

9.body: Muslim-owned Chinese eatery serving up Sichuan cuisine.
9.description: Muslim-owned Chinese eatery serving up Sichuan cuisine.
9.name: Le Fuse Cafe

10.body: Offering a taste of nostalgia, 8 Noodles is set in a 1960s style restaurant setting. Offering diners an assortment of affordably priced noodles, this cosy restaurant also serves traditional Cantonese-style roast meats.
10.description: A Chinese noodle house in a 1960s setting.
10.name: 8 Noodles

11.body: Core to the Tea Chapter philosophy is appreciating tea as a mindful experience that far extends simply drinking tea. Slip into nostalgic ambiance of our historical architecture, relax to traditional classical Chinese music and experience the gentle hustle
11.description: Appreciating traditional Chinese tea beyond the hustle and bustle of Singapore
11.name: Tea Chapter Trading Pte. Ltd.

12.body: This stall serves the popular Hakka Chinese dish in many other ways.
12.description: This stall serves the popular Hakka Chinese dish in many other ways.
12.name: Jason Niang Dou Fu

13.body: A Chinese restaurant that's popular for its affordable, fuss-free food.
13.description: A Chinese restaurant that's popular for its affordable, fuss-free food.
13.name: North South Cuisine

14.body: JING is a contemporary Chinese restaurant represented by Cantonese and Singapore influences. Using top grade internationally sourced seasonal ingredients in timeless dishes, guests can expect to be served in a modern, understated space with opulent touches overseeing the beautiful waterfront at Marina Bay.
14.description: JING is a contemporary Chinese restaurant represented by Cantonese and Singapore influences.
14.name: Jing Seafood Restaurant

15.body: Puncak is a Halal eatery that specialises in Chinese cuisine. Some of their popular dishes include Honeydew Chicken Noodle, Wanton Noodles and Claypot Rice. Locals boast about their Fried Wonton, served piping hot and coated with a crispy yellow outer layer. Dip it in mayonnaise and sweet black soya sauce for added oomph.
15.description: Indulge in a Halal Chinese cuisine only at Puncak, which serves delicious and piping hot dishes.
15.name: Puncak

16.body: Satisfy your sweet tooth at Mei Heong Yuen Dessert. This joint specialises in traditional Chinese desserts such as bird’s nest soup and yam paste, but you could also opt for other treats like durian mochi and one of their snow ice creations (which come in an array of flavours, from lychee to green tea). Other highlights include warm Chinese desserts like peanut and black sesame pastes, or the classic mango puree with pomelo and sago offering a welcome respite from our warm tropical weather.
16.description: A local heritage brand specialising in selling a variety of hot and cold Chinese desserts
16.name: Mei Heong Yuen Dessert (Temple Street Outlet)

17.body: Visitors seeking authentic hawker fare in a more refined setting should head to StraitsKitchen at Grand Hyatt Singapore, Singapore’s first SG Clean Quality Mark hotel. Smart casual dress code applies. This restaurant serves a sumptuous buffet spread of local favourites (lunch: S$62++; dinner: S$72++), including dishes of the Peranakans (Straits-born people of Chinese and Malay/Indonesian heritage), Chinese and Indian cuisine, and popular hawker staples such as satay (grilled meat skewers), laksa (spicy coconut milk-based noodle soup) and chicken rice, all in a chic steel-and-marble dining hall. For dessert, the freshly made nonya kueh (bite-sized snacks or desserts) and homemade ice creams are not to be missed at StraitsKitchen. Child rates available.
17.description: Enjoy a sumptuous buffet spread of local delights ranging from Peranakan to Chinese to Indian dishes at this chic restaurant.
17.name: StraitsKitchen

18.body: Tucked between Ann Siang and Erskine Road is one of Singapore’s most famous handmade Chinese pastry shops, Tong Heng. The  bakery offers signature melt-in-your-mouth diamond shaped egg tarts. Other must-try traditional pastries include Baked Pork Bun and Wife Pastry (a traditional Cantonese flaky pastry with sweet filling), refreshing Chinese desserts like Chilled Rose Peach Gum, Warm Almond Soup, and many others. It also offers a wide selection of delicious cookies in beautifully designed tins or jars of fragrant kaya (a traditional jam made from coconut and eggs).
18.description: A traditional Chinese bakery known for their diamond shaped egg tarts, which has been in business since the 1930s.
18.name: Tong Heng

19.body: 藝 yì, which stands for art in the Chinese language, references centuries of culinary mastery to bring the best in the fine art of Chinese dining. The classy restaurant features artistic adaptations of provincial cuisine from all the different regions of China. The restaurant brings guests on an exploration to China’s diverse cultural regions with dishes incorporating single sourced and seasonal ingredients with a contemporary approach. Its signature dish, the Hundred-ring Cucumber with Sea Whelk, is skilfully sliced and served with refreshing vinaigrette and sea whelk—presenting a refreshing experience for visitors’ taste buds. Allergens and dietary specifications are highlighted in the menu and staff will able to assist with any dietary requirements.
19.description: Chinese fine dining restaurant 藝 yÌ brings out the best in cuisine from different regions of China.
19.name: 藝 yÌ by Jereme Leung
